bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 166, Number 28 (Tuesday, February 11, 2020)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. ZELDIN:H.R. 5846.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article 1, Section 8 of the United States Constitution.[Page H1046]

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Financial Services.

summary.text:
Neutralizing Unfair Chinese Export Subsidies Act of 2020

This bill places requirements on the Department of the Treasury related to negotiations to end export credit financing.

Specifically, the bill requires Treasury to submit a strategy for U.S. advocacy and cooperation with allies and partners. Such strategy shall encompass how to (1) ensure compliance by China with the financial terms and conditions of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development Arrangement on Officially Supported Export Credits, and (2) eliminate subsidized export financing programs and other forms of export subsidies.

Additionally, the bill shifts certain requirements for negotiations related to ending export credit financing that currently lay with the President to the Department of the Treasury.

bill.title: Neutralizing Unfair Chinese Export Subsidies Act of 2020

item.title: Neutralizing Unfair Chinese Export Subsidies Act of 2020
To provide for working with allies to seek increased compliance by China with certain OECD export credit standards.
Neutralizing Unfair Chinese Export Subsidies Act of 2020

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Financial Services.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
